First Create a user named 's3' and set their shell to '/bin/bash'
Next, create a user named 's6' amd set their shell to '/bin/sh'
Create a folder named 'server' on the root of the drive
Create an 's3' and a 's6' folder beneath /server
Set the two new users home directories to point to your new folders
Now create a group called 's3ands6' and put both users in it. Do not change the users primary group
Creating multiple directories Now create the following directory structure: /server/s3 /server/s3/private /server/s3/public /server/s3/shared /server/s6 /server/s6/private /server/s6/public
Make s3 the owner and group of their home directory and everything in it
Make s6 the owner and group of their home directory and everything in it
Now set the group of /server/s3/shared to the s3ands6 group

Set the permissions on /server/s3 such that the owner has full access and the group will have no access. To make the public folder and shared folder accessible, set the permissions on the home directory to allow EVERYONE to change into, but not list the contents of the home folders
Set the permissions on /server/s3/public such that everyone can read write and execute files in that folder
Set the permissions on /server/s3/private such that the owner has full permissions and everyone else has none
Set the permissions on /server/s3/shared such that the owner and group have full permissions and everyone else has none

Set the permissions on /server/s6 such that the owner has full access and the group will have no access. To make the public folder accessible, set the permissions on the home directory to allow EVERYONE to change into, but not list the contents of the home folders.
Set the permissions on /server/s6/public such that everyone can read write and execute files in that folder
Set the permissions on /server/s6/private such that the owner has full permissions and everyone else has none
Change the s6 user shell to /bin/bash
Add the s6 user to the 'sudo' group
Switch users to become the s6 user, but DO NOT switch to the s6 users environment variables
As the s6 user, change to the s3 users home directory
Run the command 'ls -la' and confirm you cannot see any files
As the s6 user change to the shared folder beneath the s3 users home directory
Copy the file /bin/cat to a new file /server/s3/shared/supercat
Set supercat's SUID bit so it executes as root for everyone
First try to use the normal cat program to view /etc/shadow. Type 'cat /etc/shadow'
Setting the SUID bit...
Set the file permissions on /server/s3/shared/runme.sh so both owner and group have only read and execute and everyone else has no permissions
As the s6 user try running the file. Type '/server/s3/shared/runme.sh'
Several steps!
Use sudo with -g

Complete Lab 22: Managing Processes question 1
What is the process id of the backdoor? Type echo followed by the process id number.
What is the process id of the backdoor's parent process? Type echo followed by the parent process id number.
Retreive a copy of the backdoor and execute it. What is flag that is printed when you run the backdoor?
Now, kill the backdoor process.

pkill command This task requires the use of the pkill command. The pkill command has the capability to kill processes based on the commands that contain a search term. Because you know part of the process name, you can find every process that contains backdoor and kill it.

Create ALLOWED_OUT chain in filter table
Create ALLOWED_IN chain in filter table
Move processing to the ALLOWED_IN chain
Move processing to the ALLOWED_OUT chain Insert into the second position on the OUTPUT chain a jump to the new ALLOWED_OUT chain. Jump to ALLOWED_OUT not configured correctly!
Move rules from OUTPUT to ALLOWED_OUT

Allow port 22 in the ALLOWED_IN chain
Delete the PREPREFILTER chain from the nat table A chain has been added to the nat table. Your need task is to delete the chain from the table:
Flush the rules from the PREPREFILTER chain
Delete the PREPREFILTER chain from the nat table You can now delete the chain by running "iptables -t nat -X PREPREFILTER". PREPREFILTER chain NOT deleted from nat table!

You have your backup, now flush everything
Flush the nat table too
